messageBody:
Santiago,
You might want to check out JMock for you cause. http://www.jmock.org/getting-started.html

Thanks,
Anuj kaushal


smatalonga <smatalonga@...> wrote:
Hi,

I've been going over this thread but could not find the answer for my
problem.

I am working wiht a 3rd party api. Where I have to extend one of their
clases and Inteact via a receiveAsyncMessage(Message) method.

The Message class ha no default or public constructor.

class Message extends EventObject {
protected final String type;
/**
* some more properties
*/
Message(String type,....){

}

}

How can I mock this class?

I want to be able to create fake messages to test my code without
having to run the server and the client application.

Thanks for the help,
Santiago

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Kathy Van Stone <kvs@a...> wrote:
>
> ferrismatic wrote:
>
> >
> >
> > Hello:
> >
> > I have a situation where I need a mock object for a vendor provided
> > class. I connect to a data provider via an IP address. They have
> > provided an API which I implement, and get callbacks from them with
> > the data. I can create a mock of one of their classes - but since
> > it's not hooked up to their IP, there's no data in it.
> >
> > I suppose I could decompile their class and put some data in it - but
> > at that point, am I really testing my interaction with their classes -
> > or with one of my own munging?
> >
> > Thanks for any suggestions.
> >
>
> About a year ago I had to get our application to work with another
> application over JNI (they only had a C/C++ interface). I did the
> following:
>
> 1. I wrote an interface that described how I wanted to access the
remote
> API in terms of my
> application (the Facade pattern)
>
> 2. I wrote an implementation of that interface using fake data for
> testing the rest of the system.
>
> 3. I wrote tests of the real implementation against the real API (which
> accessed a local copy of the remote application). As the real API was
> not always going to be available (licensing issues), these were
> separated from the rest of the tests. Some of these tests were also
> "Learning tests" to make certain I understood the remote API (and,
in my
> case, JNI, as this
> was my first JNI project).
>
> I thus ended up with three kinds of tests:
>
> 1. Learning tests to make certain I understood the API (and also
> protecting me from changes to the API).
>
> 2. Tests of my real implementation of the interface against remote
API.
> These tests were separated from the standard set of tests.
>
> 3. Tests of my application against a fake implementation. These were
> part of the main set of tests.
>
> I hope this helps,
>
> Kathy Van Stone
> kvs@a...
